entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: One step after the other - Long-distance hiking
entry.content:
From one extreme hobby to another: While rileyrainey enjoys jumping down from huge heights, I love hiking the extra mile. Or better said: hiking over thousands of kilometers, one day after another, one step at a time. I am happy to take on the baton in the SAP  Community Hobbies series and introduce my passion of long-distance hiking to you. 

Who I am?

Hi! I am Jan Rumig from Germany, a Chief Development Architect in the SAP Business Technology Platform. As a contrast to my daily office hours, I spend most of my leisure time with hiking, reading about hiking and taking pictures of our beautiful nature while hiking. One could say I breathe hiking. Since recently, I also found passion in standing in front of big audiences and talk about my adventures.

How my love for hiking began

I wasn‚Äôt even born yet when my parents first took me to the mountains. It all began back then in Ramsau am Dachstein, where I spent several weeks each year with my family. During my teenage years, I went on my first solo hikes there. Later, as a young adult, I started to intensify this passion - spending one or two weeks a year in mountain regions, always with a fixed base. At that time, I already had the desire to explore new and more distant regions, but often I lacked hiking companions, and I didn‚Äôt quite have the courage to set out on my own.

First Solo Adventures: Portugal, the Balkans, and Beyond

Everything changed after a painful breakup. From that moment on, there was no holding back. My first solo hike took me to the Rota Vicentina, the Fishermen‚Äôs Trail in Portugal - one of the most beautiful coastal hikes in the world. Many more regions followed: Serbia, Romania, Ukraine, the Peaks of the Balkans Trail, Colombia, and several others. I was infected with hiking fever. The more I saw and experienced, the more I wanted to discover. Between trips to faraway countries, I explored the Alps. And even on weekends, I felt the urge to head outdoors. Luckily, I live close to wonderful hiking regions - the Odenwald, the Palatinate, or the Black Forest are my weekly playgrounds.

üéßSome details of the Peaks of the Balkans, I discussed in a podcast, in German only: Wanderwach & Kaffee.

Beautiful coastline on the Rota Vicentina

Gjeravica, highest mountain of Cosovo

Inspiration from New Zealand: Te Araroa

But deep down, I had always carried an unfulfilled desire to experience a truly long and demanding adventure. At first, my own inner doubts held me back: You won‚Äôt manage this, something could happen to you‚Ä¶ You can still do such an adventure at a later point in time. Then, in 2022, two colleagues of mine passed away unexpectedly. It was a harsh reminder not to postpone life. I asked my boss whether I could take six months off. Luckily, I had accumulated 162 vacation days over the years. My leave was approved. Some years earlier, I had heard of the Te Araroa in New Zealand - 3,000 km through breathtaking landscapes. So, over the turn of the year 2023/2024, I set off for New Zealand. The Te Araroa is considered one of the toughest long-distance trails in the world - and for good reason. While it is fully marked, it often leads through pathless terrain. In total, I had to ford around 100 rivers, some of them chest-deep. Much of the forest felt like jungle, and the ‚Äútrail‚Äù was often nothing more than a mudfest. Yet, perhaps because of these challenges, it became an unforgettable experience that profoundly changed me and my outlook on life. And ‚Äúunfortunately,‚Äù it also sparked an insatiable appetite for long-distance hiking and adventure. I decided then and there to take more extended breaks in the future, balancing my career with my passion for the outdoors.

üéßPodcast epiode about all the details of my hike through New Zealand, in German only: Holy Sheep Neuseeland. 

Typical New Zealand forestSunrise over the Richmond RangesJan above Lake ConstanceRainbow over mountain hutEnd of Te Araroa trail in Bluff

Discovering my homeland

No sooner had one adventure ended than I wanted to plan the next. But after those long-haul flights to New Zealand, I didn‚Äôt want to put such a strain on the environment again. That‚Äôs when everything came together: during my trek in New Zealand, I listened to a podcast where Soulboy spoke about the creation of the North South Trail (NST). From that moment, a seed was planted: Wouldn‚Äôt it be wonderful to explore my own homeland on foot? Many of the trails that make up the NST had already been on my personal wish list for some time. And while on the Te Araroa I was just one of about 4,000 hikers per year, only around 30 verified hikers had completed the NST in its entirety so far. So, my decision was clear: in 2025, I would set out to hike the NST.
What were my expectations for the trail? I was well aware that the wilderness experience of New Zealand couldn‚Äôt be replicated in Germany - and I wasn‚Äôt looking for that. Instead, I wanted to get to know my homeland step by step, meter by meter, discovering its many facets from north to south. A few examples: the landscape begins flat as a pancake in the north and gradually grows more mountainous as you move south. Or take food: up north it‚Äôs Mettbr√∂tchen for breakfast or giant Rumkugeln from the bakery, in the Palatinate it‚Äôs Saumagen, and in the south you‚Äôre rewarded with Kaiserschmarrn. And I was eager to explore regions I‚Äôd never visited before, many of which had long been on my list. On its 3,700 kilometers, the North South Trail connects 36 certified trails leading through 30 national parks.
People often ask me which parts of the North South Trail were my favorites. Uff, that‚Äôs a tough question. Every region has something exciting to offer, and I honestly can‚Äôt narrow it down to just one. The Saar-Hunsr√ºck-Steig fascinated me because it‚Äôs so diverse and offers a little bit of everything: narrow singletracks, streams, beautiful forests, castles, and more. The Palatinate Wine Trail felt special because it‚Äôs close to my home, so I felt a sense of familiarity there - and the Palatinate people are simply warm-hearted folks. Even in the Black Forest, where I had plenty of bad weather, there were memorable sections - especially the famous Schluchtensteig. But if I had to pick what touched me the most, it‚Äôs always the high mountains. That‚Äôs why the Nagelfluhkette near the end of the trail truly stole my heart.

üéßSome stories and more details of my walk through Germany can be found in this podcast episode, in German only: Off the Path.

Deer under treesRed KitePalatinate forestMountain in cloudsJan above Oberstdorf valleyMost southern point of Germany: Haldenwanger Eck

 

What is so fascinating in long-distance hiking

As I indicated already before, I love being outdoors, experiencing all sensory impulses from nature and watching and photographing all the beauty out there. But these reasons are not specific to long-distance hiking. What makes long distances special: you have to carry all your stuff on your back, most of the times including a tent and cooking equipment. On my hike through Germany I carried a total weight of around 18 kg without water. While hiking, you reduce yourself to the most minimal needs. As a famous female German hiker, Christine Th√ºrmer, says: every day you only focus on walk, sleep, eat, repeat. If you then get a shower after several days or you buy a chocolate bar, these small things make you really, really happy.

üéß More details about the fascination of long-distance hiking, I discussed in a podcast episode, in German only: Frei Raus. 

All my stuff for a long distance hike

Special support: Trail Angels üëº

Have you ever heard about trail angels? For long-distance hikers these are true angels. These are usually private individuals that support hikers along the trail with free food or a chance for an overnight sleeping opportunity. On my trip through Germany, I stayed at 25 trail angels. Most of these stays were much better than any hotel. Sometimes there was a delicious dinner, a free bed and a rich breakfast. As most of them are also outdoorsy, I got new inspirations for future adventures. These encounters with foreign people is exactly what's missing in today's world: love towards humans that you don't know.

Reaching the final signpost

Although I enjoy every minute of my walks, it is such a wonderful feeling when you reach the final signpost at the end of your long trail. All the tension falls apart and you feel deeply relieved. I am always really proud of what I achieved with my body. Our body is the most fascinating thing. Once accommodated, it carries you everywhere like a machine. We have to cherish all of it and take care about our health. My proudest moment so far was achieving the North South Trail in Fastest known time. For the 3,700 km I only needed 96 hiking days + 2 rest days.

Everybody can do it

You have doubts if you can do the same? Don't worry. The good news is: you can. Before you start on a long hike, do some test hikes. First maybe start with a single days, then a weekender, followed by multiple days. If you feel comfortable, go for something longer. And when the day comes, the important thing is, start slowly and give your body the time it needs to accommodate to the efforts. Day by day you will feel getting stronger and more endurable. The worst thing you can do is to never start. Always remember that our life is limited. Better regret the things you've done than the things you haven't done. 

What will be next?

So, am I done with long-distance hiking now? Absolutely not - quite the opposite. The big question is simply: what‚Äôs next? For now, I think I‚Äôll choose something a little shorter. Current favorites include the High Scardus Trail through North Macedonia, Kosovo, and Albania, the Lycian Way in Turkey, or perhaps the GR20 on Corsica as an add-on. But who knows - maybe something entirely different will come my way.
Besides hiking, I discovered another related hobby: talking about my adventures. So I take my pictures and videos, convert them into visually attractive multi-vision shows, add stories and present them in front of big audiences. Let's connect if you see a chance for me to present my adventures somewhere close by to you. üòä

üéü  For readers based in Germany around Heidelberg, there is the perfect opportunity to listen first-hand about my hike through New Zealand, I will be a speaker at the wonderful Wunderwelten Festival on January 3rd.  

One of my talks about the hike through New Zealand

 

Want to know more?

You also want to start hiking? There are a lot of outdoor portals where you can easily find beautiful hikes around the place where you live. Just search for tours in your region in your favorite search engine. Additionally, contact me, I might have some proposals. üòá

You became curious to learn more about my hikes?

  • You find a lot of pictures and daily reports of my travels on my Instagram account. 
  • You can access all my hikes on Komoot.

Coming up next

I am happy to pass the baton to Marika who is introducing her hobbies singing and theatre to us. In addition she engages in meaningful volunteer work. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: SAP BTP y Estrategias de Migraci√≥n a SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay SITCDE2025 nos regal√≥ una jornada t√©cnica excepcional de la mano de Juan Pablo Barril, Experto SAP BASIS & BTP y RISE Cloud Architecture de @Kuaa_Technology Kuaatec, quien nos gui√≥ a trav√©s de dos pilares fundamentales de la transformaci√≥n digital empresarial: SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) y las estrategias de migraci√≥n a SAP S/4HANA.


SAP Business Technology Platform: Conectar e Innovar
¬øQu√© necesitan las organizaciones ganadoras?
Las empresas buscan agilidad e innovaci√≥n para competir, transformarse y prosperar:

  • Reaccionar r√°pidamente a los cambios del mercado
  • Lograr resultados excepcionales y avances innovadores
  • Diferenciarse de la competencia
  • Capacidad de conectar aplicaciones, procesos y datos dispares

Las Tres √Åreas de SAP BTP
1. App Dev & Automation
Experiencia low-code/no-code y herramientas pro-code
Automatizaci√≥n rob√≥tica de procesos
Gesti√≥n del flujo de trabajo

2. Data & Analytics
Productos de datos listos para la empresa
Toma de decisiones aumentada por IA
Plataforma de datos abiertos

3. Integration
3,800+ integraciones preconstruidas
4,400+ APIs y gr√°ficos de datos
Integraci√≥n de procesos E2E para soluciones SAP y no-SAP

Como mencion√≥ Juan Pablo: "Estos proyectos de BTP son altamente muy r√°pidos, son proyectos cortos de dos, tres meses y las empresas necesitan esos cambios inmediatos."

SAP Build: La Soluci√≥n Unificada
SAP Build Apps

  • Funciones visuales en la nube para aplicaciones de pila completa
  • Desarrollo colaborativo entre negocio y desarrolladores
  • Soporte multicanal para m√≥viles y web
  • Integraci√≥n v√≠a API REST y OData

SAP Build Process Automation

  • Flujos de trabajo con arrastrar y soltar
  • Soluciones predise√±adas
  • IA incorporada para generaci√≥n de procesos

Durante la presentaci√≥n mostr√≥ un ejemplo de Purchase Requisition Approval, donde Joule ayuda a generar el requisition y crea autom√°ticamente el flujo de trabajo completo.

Joule Studio
Permite crear agentes de IA personalizados:

  • Comprenden y resuelven problemas comerciales espec√≠ficos
  • Experiencia conversacional unificada
  • Seguridad integrada de nivel empresarial

¬øPor D√≥nde Empezar?
Juan Pablo comparti√≥ recursos clave:

  • SAP BTP Guidance Framework: Gu√≠as de decisi√≥n, arquitecturas de referencia y mejores pr√°cticas
  • SAP Discovery Center: Casos de uso, historias de clientes y estimador de costos
  • SAP Learning: M√°s de 100 SAP Learning Journeys gratuitos
  • Free Tier and Trial: Probar SAP BTP sin costo inicial

"BTP se puede usar much√≠simo... todo esto se puede tambi√©n utilizar con una cuenta free trial. No te requiere hardware, lo √∫nico que vas a tener que instalar es un cloud connector."

Estrategias de Migraci√≥n a SAP S/4HANA
Brownfield vs Greenfield
Brownfield (Conversi√≥n de Sistema)

  • Conversi√≥n t√©cnica completa de SAP ERP existente a S/4HANA
  • Utilizar tecnolog√≠a e instalaciones existentes
  • Comenzar r√°pidamente
  • Menor riesgo

Greenfield (Nueva Implementaci√≥n)

  • Reingenier√≠a y simplificaci√≥n de procesos
  • Elegir nueva tecnolog√≠a
  • Realizar carga de datos inicial
  • Mayor planificaci√≥n inicial

SAP Readiness Check: El Punto de Partida
Juan Pablo explic√≥ que esta herramienta indica qu√© tan preparado est√° el sistema para migrar a S/4HANA, analizando:

  • Compatibilidad t√©cnica (versi√≥n, add-ons, extensiones)
  • C√≥digo ABAP y funciones obsoletas
  • Rendimiento y dimensionamiento
  • Procesos de negocio y oportunidades de mejora
  • Recomendaciones Fiori

"Se hace siempre previo a hacer las conversiones para tener una hoja de ruta real de c√≥mo estamos parados hoy d√≠a del sistema y todos los ajustes que hay que hacer."

SAP Simplification Check
Muestra qu√© cambios concretos hacer en procesos, datos y funciones:
Verificaci√≥n de Relevancia

Identifica qu√© Simplification Items aplican
Dimensiona el impacto funcional y t√©cnico

Verificaci√≥n de Consistencia

  • Comprueba que datos y procesos cumplan las nuevas estructuras
  • Detecta inconsistencias antes de la conversi√≥n

Conversi√≥n de Sistema: Fases Principales
Fase de Preparaci√≥n:

  • Requerimientos del sistema
  • Maintenance Planner
  • Pre checks
  • Custom code preparation
  • Unicode conversion, OS & DB Version, SPAM Version

Fase de Realizaci√≥n:

  • SUM (Software Update Manager)
  • Migraci√≥n DB
  • Software Update
  • Data Conversion

"Es important√≠simo actualizar la SPAM. Es muy important√≠simo porque las empresas vienen de sistemas viejos y tenemos que validar las versiones compatibles de base de datos y sistema operativo."

El Desaf√≠o del C√≥digo Custom
Juan Pablo fue claro sobre el mayor desaf√≠o:
"La tarea m√°s ardua es todos los reportes que vamos a ver... la idea de SAP en la conversi√≥n es limpiar y tratar de minimizar al m√≠nimo el tema de los desarrollos."
"Hay que analizar si esas aplicaciones llevarlas a c√≥digo en BTP o directamente reemplazarla. Porque en muchos casos hay esa funcionalidad, alguien desarroll√≥ algo y hoy d√≠a est√° disponible en las aplicaciones est√°ndar."


Agradecemos a Kuaa technology por su patrocinio del SAP Inside Track Paraguay SITCDE2025, haciendo posible estos espacios de aprendizaje en la comunidad SAP.
Un agradecimiento especial a Juan Pablo Barril por compartir su conocimiento t√©cnico sobre SAP BTP y las estrategias de migraci√≥n a S/4HANA de manera clara y pr√°ctica.
¬°Gracias al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay!

entry.title: SAP Q4 first meetup highlights
entry.content:
This is the last quarter of the year 2025. We organized another SAP event for the Columbus location. This event became special because of two things. First, a few new members joined the event online on Google Meet, and second, we plan to organize SAP Inside Track at the Columbus location. New members who joined the event for the first time are Pavan Sarda, Sumit Maloo and Vishal Gupta. They all introduced themselves, their experience, type of industry experience etc.

 

We got very good inputs for organizing the SAP Inside Track. Suggestions were given to organize the following events: speaker, workshops, tea, and lunch. Topics can be related to the latest innovations in SAP S4HANA, industry-specific knowledge, Role of artificial intelligence in industry. Workshops can be conducted on introducing SAP S4HANA knowledge in the education system.

The next plan of action will be to contact SAP Germany and share the plan and arrange the approval to organize the event.

entry.title: When Physical Identity Turns Digital: Rethinking Traceability in Enterprise Integration
entry.content:
Modern large scale integration architectures are powered by advance resurgence of observability, distributed tracing, and correlations.
The advancement in observability and analytics platform, provides confidence to extend the reach of integration and envision more on horizon.

The traceability improvement is not limited to the digital world.
The evolutionary spiral is expanding in the realms of supply chain operations, infobahn and data reservoirs.

With EPCIS(Electronic Product Code Information Services) upgrade to version 2.0, the business events, propagating downstream, upstream or in the reverse logistic channel- can be wrapped in json-ld/json file and can be upserted at each stage of the supply chain to the next.

Key EPC identifiers are GTIN, SGTIN(Combination of serial number and GTIN), GRAI(Global Returnable Asset Identifier) and SSCC(Serial Shipping Container Code).

The core idea of this blog is to use the physical EPC(Electronic Product Code) identifiers as W3C trace context identifiers such as traceparent and tracestate.
Each integrated (and OTEL observable) cloud/web application , in case forwards, these identifiers from one system to other, as part of HTTP headers then the organizations can establish strong correlation between physical supply chain events and digital system interactions. A major leverage point of these headers, would be the scenarios, where asynchronous request and response is used at larger scale for e.g. usage of SAP Event Mesh, JMS Queues etc.

For supply-chain leaders and digital-transformation executives, the multi-fold benefits are clear:
a unified, correlated view of physical events and digital flows, enabling deeper insights, quicker decisions, and more successful operations. From a different vantage point, the digital trails set by W3C trace context, reflects the recording of physical events by the digital systems as traceparent/tracestate, whenever the system digitally observes a product related event(specified by EPCIS jason-ld file) passing through it.

Following are few methods to set/derive the W3C trace context using epc ids:
- Set traceparent as hash of epc id.
- Set tracestate as epc id.
- Set trace-id field of traceparent as epc id(if epc id is a UUID).

Below you would find an http client snippet which performs the above suggested steps.  The snippet below is only for didactic purpose.

with open("epcis_payload.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
    payload = json.load(file)

#epcis file itself can carry traceparent as part of extension field; if present extract and set it 
traceParent = None
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceparent' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceParent = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceparent']

#Otherwise, hash the epc id and set traceparent with the obtained value post hashing             
if traceParent == None:            
    # Create deterministic 16 byte trace ID
    if 'epcList' in payload:
        traceId = hashlib.sha256(str(payload['epcList']).encode()).hexdigest()[:32]
    else:
        traceId = str(uuid.uuid4())[:32]
    span_uuid = uuid.uuid4()
    spanId = str(span_uuid)
    #traceparent = 00-<trace-id>-<span-id>-01
    traceParent = '00-' + traceId + '-' + spanId[:16] + '-01'

#Add traceparent as http header 
headers.update({"traceparent": traceParent})

#epcis file itself can carry tracestate as part of extension field; if present extract and set it
traceState = ""
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceState' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceState = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceState']

#Otherwise, set the tracestate as epc id           
if traceState == "":
        if 'epcList' in payload: 
            # Create tracestate from EPCIS Id
            traceState = 'epcList = ' + str(payload['epcList'])
        if 'inputEPCList' in payload:
            # Extend the tracestate
            if 'epcList' in traceState:
                traceState = traceState + ',' + 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
            else:
                traceState = 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
        if 'outputEPCList' in payload:
            traceState = traceState + ',' + 'outputEPCList = ' + str(payload['outputEPCList'])

#Add tracestate as http header 
headers.update({"tracestate": traceState})

#POST request
response = requests.post(url, auth=HTTPBasicAuth(username, password), headers=headers, json=payload)

The EPCIS json-ld/json file forwarder, can even send traceparent and tracestate(as part of extension field of the file) along with business event details.

In the Runtime Configuration of Integration Flow, set traceparent and tracestate as allowed headers (as shown below):

One can even think of embedding the returned MPL ID (from SAP Integration Suite. as part of HTTP response), into tracestate for further transmission down the lane. Later, the predecessor MPL IDs and Integration Flows involved, in processing, the EPCIS json-Ld, can be determined as per explanation in following help documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/using-ids-to-filter-messages?locale=en-US&q=predecessor

An EPCIS event describes what, where, why, when and how about the business event. Taking an abstract look to overall above suggested scheme-  it would appear as if a new dimension is added to EPCIS event i.e. who(digitally viewed the event).


Now imagine that the integrated systems are streaming these message headers to data lake such as SAP Business Data Cloud or to a data federation system. This would then open a new portal to the world of federated tracing and large scale correlation. By indexing with traceparent, the correlated messages, in data lake and federation system, can be brought together.

Additionally, the W3C trace context headers can be stored as custom header properties, in message processing logs, in SAP Integration Suite. These settings can be achieved by (AI assisted) groovy scripting in SAP Integration Suite.

Below snippet reflects the extraction of traceparent and tracestate from the http header and setting the same as MPL's custom headers.

def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(attachmentName, body, "text/plain")
    } 
    def traceid = message.getHeader("traceparent", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("traceparent", traceid)
    
    def tracestate = message.getHeader("tracestate", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("tracestate", tracestate)

One can then view these custom headers, in Message Monitor section of SAP Integration Suite, as shown below:

 

The added custom attributes would be then visible, in SAP Cloud ALM as well, provided the respective SAP Integration Suite and  SAP Cloud ALM tenants are already dovetailed.

Harvest above insights and ideas and redefine the observability of supply chains !


References:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/message-processing-log-text-view?locale=en-US
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/raw-data-inbound-logs?locale=en-US

entry.title: Recap SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025: A Celebration of Community, Innovation, and Shared Knowledge.
What a journey it's been! Last November 14th, we wrapped up the 9th edition of SAP Inside Track Barcelona, and I'm still buzzing from the energy, connections, and incredible moments we shared together.

More Than Just an Event

There's something truly special about SAP Inside Track. Yes, it's about SAP technologies, innovation, and learning ‚Äî but at its core, it's about people. It's about creating a space where developers, consultants, architects, and SAP enthusiasts can come together, share their experiences, and build genuine connections that go beyond the professional realm.
This year, we brought together +100 passionate individuals in a historic Modernist building in the heart of Barcelona. From the moment the doors opened until the last photo was taken the spirit of community was palpable.


Knowledge That Inspires

The quality of sessions this year was outstanding. Our speakers delivered thought-provoking presentations covering the full spectrum of SAP technologies:

  • AI and Innovation: From Vision AI applications in quality management to conversational AI solutions that let you "talk" to your data
  • SAP BTP: Deep dives into the Business Technology Platform and its transformative capabilities of SAP Hana with Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph
  • Next-Generation Talent: Insights into how SAP University Alliances is empowering the future of our ecosystem
  • SAP BTP Real-World Solutions: Practical implementations of SAP Integration Suite, CAP, FIORI, Printing solution, Identity Services, sand more
  • Freelance market barometer 2025

A special highlight was the Spanish final of the AUSIA Hackathon -  AUSAPE final,  where we witnessed incredible creativity and problem-solving. Congratulations to SDG Group for their winning solution combining AI, data modeling, and planning on SAP BTP, and to Brait Partners for their innovative electronic invoicing automation platform. Both teams proved that new technologies have real, tangible applications in today's business landscape.

The Power of Community: A New Milestone

Speaking of community strength, I'm thrilled to share some exciting news that perfectly exemplifies what we've built together: three new extraordinary members from our community have just joined the SAP Champions program! This recognition is a testament to the collaborative spirit, knowledge sharing, and genuine passion that defines our Barcelona and Spain SAP ecosystem. It's proof that when we come together, support each other, and actively contribute to the community, incredible things happen. These achievements don't belong to individuals alone ‚Äî they're a reflection of the nurturing environment we've created through events like SIT Barcelona. Congratulations to our new Champions; you make us all proud! üèÜ @AAncos @DanielMateo @Lluis 


Gratitude to Those Who Made It Possible

None of this would have been possible without our amazing volunteering speakers who shared their expertise, experiences, and passion. Your willingness to prepare, present, and engage with attendees is what makes SIT Barcelona such a valuable learning experience. Thank you for your time, your knowledge, and your commitment to our community.
To our sponsors ‚Äî thank you for believing in the power of community events. Your support enables us to create these spaces where innovation flourishes and connections are made. You're not just supporting an event; you're investing in the growth and development of the SAP ecosystem in Spain.

And I must give a huge, heartfelt thank you to the entire SIT Barcelona organizing team, Llu√≠s, Mireia, Enric, Losel, Imma and Saul. Your dedication, countless hours of planning, problem-solving on the fly, and unwavering passion made this 9th edition possible. You are the backbone of this community, and working alongside each of you has been an absolute privilegeüíô

The Heart of It All: Community

What sets SAP Inside Track apart from other tech events is the genuine sense of community we've built together over these nine years. It's in the coffee conversations, the spontaneous debates about architecture patterns, the exchange of LinkedIn profiles, and yes, even in the collective patience when life happens (like dog medication time!).
I've seen friendships form, collaborations spark, and careers transform through the connections made at SIT Barcelona. Whether you're a first-time attendee or a veteran of all nine editions, everyone is welcomed with open arms into this wonderful ecosystem we've created together.

Looking Ahead

As we celebrate the success of our 9th edition, we're already excited about what's to come. The 10th anniversary of SIT Barcelona is on the horizon, and we have a feeling it's going to be something truly special.
To everyone who attended, spoke, sponsored, organized, or simply spread the word ‚Äî thank you. You are the reason SAP Inside Track Barcelona exists and thrives. You are the community.
Until next year, keep innovating, keep sharing, and keep being awesome! üöÄ

P.S. ‚Äî If you missed this edition or want to be part of this amazing community, stay tuned for announcements about SIT Barcelona 2026. Trust me, you don't want to miss the 10th anniversary!

entry.title: How I Escaped Browser Tab Hell: A Lesson in Choosing the Right AI Tool
entry.content:
The Journey

The Problem: 10 Years of Digital Hoarding

After a decade at SAP, I was drowning in resources. My solution? Browser bookmarks that grew into an unmanageable mess. When Chrome introduced Tab Groups, I thought I'd found salvation‚Äîuntil I realized I was maintaining 200+ tabs across multiple groups. The anxiety from my digital FOMO was worse than ever.

Back to Basics (With a Twist)

I returned to curated bookmarks but with a new goal: create a "PM Toolbox" that I could easily maintain and share with colleagues across the organization. I built a clean bookmark folder and mirrored it on a wiki page.

The Maintenance Nightmare

Within weeks, reality hit: my bookmark folder evolved constantly, requiring manual wiki updates. Chrome's bookmark export format (the ancient Netscape standard) made extracting subsets error-prone and frustrating. I needed automation.

First Attempt: GenAI Fails the Coding Test

I tried using Claude 4.5 Sonnet through GenAI-XL. Despite multiple attempts, it couldn't handle Chrome's non-standard HTML format. It kept reaching for HTML parsing libraries that failed, then suggested an obscure Netscape parser that violated SAP standards. Dead end.

Second Attempt: GitHub Copilot Nails It

The next day, I switched to VSCode with GitHub Copilot. Here's what changed:
  1. I wrote clear requirements in a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file, specifically calling out the Netscape format complexity
  2. Copilot enhanced my requirements, suggesting testing coverage and documentation guidelines (80% of the final instructions came from Copilot)
  3. I switched to Agent mode and prompted: "Please create the missing files. Do not reference public code in your response." (Critical for enterprise compliance)
The result? A complete, working script‚Äîinstantly.

But it got better. When I asked for a second script to generate Confluence tables, Copilot:
  • Created the implementation
  • Built the test suite when I requested it
  • Ran the tests autonomously, discovered bugs, and fixed them‚Äîall without me asking
I was genuinely amazed.

Key Takeaways

1. Match the Tool to the Task

  • General AI (like Claude): Excellent for brainstorming, requirements refinement, and PM tasks
  • Specialized coding AI (like GitHub Copilot): Purpose-built for implementation and testing

2. Clear Requirements Are Non-Negotiable

Both attempts used AI, but only the second succeeded because I provided structured, detailed requirements upfront.

3. Embrace Test-Driven Development

Even with AI assistance, automated testing is essential. Copilot's self-correction only worked because tests exposed the bugs immediately.

4. Simple Solutions Often Win

Sometimes the answer isn't a shinier tool‚Äîit's going back to basics (curated bookmarks) with smart automation layered on top.

The Bottom Line

AI coding assistants aren't magic‚Äîthey're power tools. Like any tool, they require the right context, clear instructions, and quality controls. When you provide those, the results can be transformative.

For PMs and non-developers: you don't need to be a coder to automate your work. You just need to understand your requirements so you can clearly write them down and choose the AI tool designed for the job.

References

You can find the scripts in question here

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2025: Premios de SAP Press, los grandes ganadores de la noche
entry.content:
Durante el a√±o 2025 organizamos el primer SAP Inside Track en Paraguay Ciudad del Este, un evento hist√≥rico donde m√°s de 100 profesionales SAP se reunieron para compartir conocimientos, hacer networking y celebrar nuestra pasi√≥n por la tecnolog√≠a.


¬øPor Qu√© Participar en un SAP Inside Track?
Los eventos SAP Inside Track son espacios √∫nicos donde la comunidad SAP cobra vida:

  • Aprender de expertos con experiencia real en proyectos SAP
  • Hacer networking con consultores, desarrolladores y usuarios clave
  • Mantenerse actualizado con las √∫ltimas tendencias y mejores pr√°cticas
  • Compartir experiencias y soluciones con colegas del ecosistema SAP
  • Fortalecer la comunidad local y crear conexiones profesionales duraderas

Gracias a Todos
Nuestro m√°s sincero agradecimiento a quienes hicieron posible este evento: los asistentes por su entusiasmo y participaci√≥n, los speakers por compartir su conocimiento, los voluntarios por su dedicaci√≥n incansable, y todos los sponsors por creer en nuestra visi√≥n y apoyar el crecimiento de la comunidad SAP en Paraguay.


Un Agradecimiento Especial a SAP Press
Queremos destacar especialmente el apoyo de SAP Press, quien como patrocinador oficial del evento, contribuy√≥ significativamente a hacer de este SIT una experiencia inolvidable. SAP Press no solo aport√≥ su prestigio y respaldo al evento, sino que tambi√©n puso a disposici√≥n de los participantes 4 e-books de su cat√°logo como premios durante el evento.
Este tipo de apoyo es fundamental para motivar la participaci√≥n, premiar el compromiso de nuestra comunidad y brindar acceso a recursos de aprendizaje de primera calidad. SAP Press ha sido y contin√∫a siendo un aliado invaluable en el desarrollo profesional de miles de profesionales SAP en todo el mundo.

¬°Felicitaciones a Nuestros Ganadores!
Durante el evento, tuvimos el placer de sortear 4 e-books de SAP Press entre nuestros participantes. Nos complace anunciar a los afortunados ganadores:

  • Blanca Lezme

  • Martha Ayala Jara 

  • Pablo Jorge Berganza Carvallo

  • Vanessa Maria Jose Guillen Arg√ºello

¬°Felicitaciones a todos los ganadores! Esperamos que disfruten de sus libros y que el conocimiento adquirido les sea de gran utilidad en sus carreras profesionales.

Mirando Hacia el Futuro
El √©xito de este primer SAP Inside Track Paraguay nos llena de orgullo y nos motiva a seguir adelante. Nuestro compromiso es claro: queremos que este sea el primero de muchos eventos.
Ya estamos so√±ando con el SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2026, y esperamos contar nuevamente con el apoyo de sponsors como SAP Press, con m√°s participantes, m√°s contenido de calidad y, por supuesto, ¬°m√°s premios para nuestra comunidad!

¬øQuieres Ser Parte del Pr√≥ximo Evento?
Si participas en nuestro pr√≥ximo SAP Inside Track, no solo tendr√°s acceso a contenido de primer nivel y oportunidades de networking invaluables, sino que tambi√©n podr√°s participar en sorteos de premios como los e-books de SAP Press y otros beneficios que nuestros sponsors pondr√°n a disposici√≥n.

No te pierdas la oportunidad de ser parte de esta comunidad vibrante y en crecimiento.

Mantente atento a nuestros canales oficiales para conocer las fechas y detalles del pr√≥ximo evento. Mientras tanto, te invitamos a unirte a la SAP Community Group de Asunci√≥n para estar al d√≠a con todas las novedades.

¬°Gracias y Hasta Pronto!
Desde el equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay, queremos agradecer una vez m√°s a todos los que hicieron posible este sue√±o. Este es solo el comienzo de algo grande.

¬°Nos vemos en el pr√≥ximo SAP Inside Track Paraguay!

¬øQuieres saber m√°s sobre SAP Press y su cat√°logo de libros? Visita www.sap-press.com

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP TechEd on Tour brought the best out of Berlin, Bengaluru, and Sydney!
entry.content:
As SAP TechEd on Tour continues to inspire people around the world, our SAP community is buzzing with fresh insights, great lessons, and standout contributions from Developer Advocates, SAP Champions and Mentors, and members from local groups. This edition of our newsletter brings you some of the blog posts that dive deeper into the most talked-about topics from SAP TechEd in Berlin, Bengaluru and Sydney. Whether you joined the events in person or are catching up virtually, these resources will help you to keep the innovation energy high and inspired to thrive on the SAP topics. 

Beyond technical content, we‚Äôre also spotlighting the vibrant connections forming at the SAP Community in-person gatherings. From post-sessions reflections to personal stories, these posts reflect the passion and collaboration that make our community grow. We‚Äôre excited to share not only the knowledge but also the experiences and inspiration that emerged through the month of November. So, dive in and keep the momentum going! 

Featured Blog Posts 

Follow-up of the ‚ÄúBest of UI5‚Äú demo presented at SAP TechEd in Bengaluru 

One of the highlights of SAP TechEd on Tour was the amazing demos presented by our Community Advocates and Developer Advocates. At the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru last week, Nico Schoenteich demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements. As a follow-up to his demo presented at the Developer Keynote, he published a blog post about how to consume arbitrary web components natively in UI5 applications. Whether you were on-site and are looking for more information, or could not attend but are interested in the topic, we highly recommend checking his content for valuable advice to make the process decreasingly complicated. 

Read Nico Schoenteich blog post here 

SAP Integration Suite: guide to secure you integrations and compliance best practices  

Our SAP Community member Praveen Kumar Beera, beyond attending SAP TechEd 2025, also made sure to share more important tips on SAP Integration Suite. In his latest blog post, Praveen dives into how to implement and manage access policies effectively, focusing on the importance of securing your integrations and maintaining robust governance. His step-by-step guide has all the images, examples, and links that you need to understand how to archive a better security setup and reduce risks.  

Read Praveen kumar Beera blog post here 

SAP TechEd on Tour: Sessions using SAP Mobile Start 

SAP Mobile Start is the native entry point to the SAP Business Suite, providing access to native or web-responsive business apps along with other content and critical business information. At SAP TechEd in Berlin and Bengaluru, SAP¬¥s ‚ÄØThilo Berndt and Thomas Bruckner, covered various mobile topics at workshops called "CA260‚ÄØ‚Äì Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start". In Thomas‚Äô latest blog post, he shared a full recap with the main technical aspects and valuable material for introduction, building and deploying the base version of the extension, app integration, and extensions, plus the implementation of custom push notifications. The on-site sessions were centered on the ease of building pro-code extensions using SAP Build and specifically SAP Build Code with the‚ÄØSAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). And if you could not take part and want to have a chance to try it out, they also uploaded all the material and exercises on GitHub within the repository ‚ÄØSAP-samples/teched2025-CA260.‚ÄØ 

Read Thomas Bruckner blog post here 

Everything you need to know to start with SAP Business Data Cloud 

At SAP TechEd in Sydney, SAP¬¥s Klaus-Peter Sauer presented great sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud, bringing an insightful overview and focusing on growing solutions to the product road map. In case you had the opportunity to watch the session or could not be present but are looking for more information about the topic, recently one of our SAP community members Akhila Unnithan, published a great BDC Beginner Guide. Akhila shared the main key points to understand how the unified data platform works and how it can turn into the only source that provides everyone with a consistent and governed layer of data, whether it is for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications.‚ÄØShe also explains what the existing SAP solutions are that form the foundation (SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP BW or BW/4HANA) and what the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud are (SAP Databricks and SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services). 

Read Akhila Unnithan blog post here 

SAP Community at SAP TechEd on Tour  

SAP TechEd in Berlin: recap by SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi 

‚ÄúSuperheroes without capes‚Äú was the best term the SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi could use to describe our incredible SAP Community team. In her SAP TechEd in Berlin recap blog post, she walks through how the event was one to remember, starting with the fact that she was one of the rewarded SAP Champions who won the SAP TechEd ticket! With amazing pictures to illustrate the moments at the Developers Keynote and Community Clubhouse, Patrizia explains how she was impacted by the outgrowing Joule Agents and SAP Build, for tangible and smart automations directly from the development environment. Therefore, for her, the biggest spark is the fact that AI is no longer an experiment. Patrizia left the event feeling more inspired than ever, and honestly this is the feeling we wish for every single member of our SAP community.  

SAP TechEd in Sydney: connecting before and after 

For a lot of our SAP community members, the in-person connection is the biggest highlight of the SAP TechEd events. And in Sydney, beyond the experience of networking at the Community Theatre, the local community made sure to show up also for the pre-event Sydney Stammtisch. Organized by Mike Doyle and Jeff T., the meeting had around 70-80 attendees and plenty of insightful and honest conversations. It was also an incredible opportunity for our SAP Community Advocates, like Anne Petteroe and Josh Bentley, to finally meet in person many local group members and strengthen even more the connections that were once created online. If you attended and want to share your pictures, comment on Mike latest blog post and share with the community!   

SAP TechEd in Bengaluru: the most energetic and positive crowd  

‚ÄúThe energy, insightful conversations, and knowledge-sharing reaffirmed why this community is so special‚Äú was our SAP Mentor Mohit Bansal description of his participation at the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru, and we also believe that this is the best way to put it. Just like past events, Bengaluru is always a place full of good and high-energy people, who are always seeking more innovation, more outcomes, and more real-life connections. Some of our amazing SAP Champions and Mentors could present great sessions and bring their expertise on-site, creating one of the best atmospheres for learning with purpose. One of the main key takeaways for many participants was the accelerating adoption of Business AI worldwide, but also how the complexities of this implementation can only be conquered with the support of all our community. We would like to highly recommend that everyone who was present share more of your experience in a blog post or, in case you are a member of the local community, bring your experience details and pictures at the Bengaluru Location group posts. 

News and Events 

ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville 

Recently one of our biggest events in the United States took place in Louisville, Kentucky, and brought light to many AI improvements for developers and businesses, the constant growth of ABAP, Clean Core for digital transformation, and many other SAP topics.  SAP¬¥s Peter Spielvogel, wrote an amazing recap (blog post here) with the details of each one of his many Key Notes. But at ASUG Tech Connect, it was also an opportunity for the local community to come together, bring together ideas, and reflect on the importance of always remembering that people can grow from technological changes. Inspired by the sessions, Peter brought the question in his blog post: ‚ÄûHow can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issues‚Äù, and we also believe that all these are mandatory self-reflecting questions. Did you take part? Do you have any other great thoughts about it? Share with us! 

SAP Webinar Open Source: Efficient Microservices Delivery with Project Konfidence 

This week, on December 4th, the SAP Open Source team is hosting another incredible webinar. This edition will be focused on Project Konfidence, a new open source that transforms the delivery of microservice-based SaaS applications. The discussion will be held by Sarah M√ºller, engineering manager and Konfidence project lead at SAP, and Timon Sch√ºle, head of a software delivery framework at SAP, and hosted by Ulrike Fempel, SAP Open Source Program Office. Make sure to watch out for the time according to your time zone: 3 pm CET, 9 am EST and 7h30 pm IST.  Registration link for the event is here and more details about the event on the blog post here.  

Hobbies Series: Long-distance hiking 

We love to see that even with a month full of work like November was for most of us, our community members are still seeking life balance and taking their time for their passions. The SAP Community Hobbies Series, started by Moshe Naveh, inspired SAP¬¥s Jan Rumig to share more about his love for hiking over thousands of kilometers. In his latest blog post, he explains that everything began with a family tradition that later became more intense, as he started spending two weeks exploring mountain regions. Illustrating with iconic pictures of his adventures in Portugal, New Zeeland, and Germany, for Jan the most wonderful feeling is when he reaches the final signpost after a long trail. If you are interested in starting to hike, we believe this content will give you the right motivation!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Cloud integration Message Usage analytics details
entry.content:
Introduction

We are excited to share the latest improvements in SAP Integration Suite designed to support key business scenarios related to consumption-based usage tracking.

With these enhancements, users can now gain deeper insights into message consumption across their integration flows and easily download consolidated monthly usage reports.

Before we dive in, you can refer to the definitions of Instance and Message in Integration Suite here:

  • Tenant definition
  • Message definition

 

How to check Cloud Integration capability consumptions as a Subaccount Admin

If you are a subaccount admin and want to know the consumption of the cloud integration capability in Integration Suite service, follow these steps:

  1. Open your subaccount where Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service is activated.
  2. In the left navigation pane, click on Usage Analytics. This page displays the consumption details for all services.
  3. You can select a date range (Period) to view usage for a specific timeframe.
  4. After selecting the required period, the table will show detailed consumption for all services. In the table, check the ‚ÄúService Plan‚Äù column for entries related to Integration Suite ‚Äì messages.
  5. For Cloud Integration (CPI) messages, two entries are important:
    1. Total Cloud Integration Messages (e.g., 658 messages)
    2. Excluded Cloud Integration Messages (Only SAP to SAP) (e.g., 320 messages)
  6. Total Cloud Integration (CPI) Chargeable Messages = Total Cloud Integration Messages - Excluded Cloud Integration Messages.

 

 

In case we want to cross-verify this data at each integration flow level/MPL level, we need to navigate to the Messages Usage tile and follow the below steps:

  1. Ensure your user has the required role (PI_Administrator).
  2. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions under the Services tab.
  3. Click Go to Application.
  4. Open the Monitoring tab and select Integrations and APIs.
  5. Scroll down to find the Messages Usage tile and click it.

On initial load, it will show the data for the current month.

 

 

Background

As many of you know, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite already provides double-click metering details for every integration flow execution.

Based on valuable feedback from our customers, this detailed view has proven useful in:

  • Troubleshooting message volume spikes
  • Identifying specific integration flow that contributes the most in message consumption
  • Understanding how key components (such as Splitter, Retry, or SAP-to-SAP Original Content) impact billable messages

These details are crucial for transparency and cost management, as outlined in the message definition documentation.

 

What‚Äôs New

Many customers expressed the need for a monthly consolidated Excel report for each integration flow ‚Äî including package-level information.
With this new enhancement, users can now:

  • View consolidated monthly message consumption per integration flow and per package
  • Download the report directly from the Message Usage tile in a single click
  • Share usage data easily with Lines of Business (LoBs) for further analysis and discussions

 

Access the Message Usage tile explained above.

  1. Default view shows the current month.

When you open the Message Usage tile, the dashboard automatically loads data for the current month, giving you an immediate overview of your latest message consumption trends.

  1. New Enhancement ‚Äì Below the chart you will see the consolidated table

This enhanced table provides:

  • Each integration flow‚Äôs total message count, including SAP-to-SAP messages
  • The package name associated with each integration flow
    This consolidated view helps you quickly understand usage distribution across packages and identify high-volume integrations.
  1. Download the monthly consolidated report

Simply click the Download button to export the full current monthly report.

 

 

 

Now try to get the previous month‚Äôs data

We provide up to 1 year of historical data. To get the previous month‚Äôs details, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the previous month‚Äôs first and last date

Use the Select Date Range option and choose the start and end dates of the month you want to retrieve.

  1. View the refreshed consolidated table

Once the date range is applied, the table below will automatically refresh, showing the consolidated message usage for the selected month.

  1. Download the monthly consolidated data

Click the Download button to export the full month‚Äôs report.
This file can be used for internal reviews, consumption analysis, or cost-related discussions with business teams.

 

 

Advanced Settings for Better Table Control

Along with the consolidated table, we also provide an Advanced Settings option.
Using this feature, you can:

  • Sort the data based on column
  • Filter records to focus on specific integration flows or packages
  • Adjust or reorder columns to view the information in the format that best suits your analysis

These options give you more flexibility to analyse message consumption in .

 

 

Enhanced Troubleshooting

This new capability extends our existing metering feature, which already helps users:

  • Investigate message spikes
  • Drill down into detailed metering data for specific integration flows
  • Use the interactive charts to visualize data based on selected metrics

Now, with the consolidated reporting feature, you get both detailed troubleshooting views and high-level monthly summaries ‚Äî in one place.

Conclusion

Your feedback has been helpful in shaping these improvements ‚Äî and we‚Äôd love to hear more!
Please share your thoughts, experiences, or suggestions for additional insights you‚Äôd like to see in Cloud Integration Capability.

Basic Trials ‚Äî –æ–∑–Ω–∞–π–æ–º–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—è –∑ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç–∞–º–∏ SAP –∑ –æ–±–º–µ–∂–µ–Ω–∏–º–∏ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∞–º–∏ –∞–¥–º—ñ–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ç–æ—Ä–∞ —Ç–∞ –∑—Ä–∞–∑–∫–∞–º–∏ –¥–∞–Ω–∏—Ö. –ó–∞ –ø–æ—Å–∏–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º –≤–∏ –∑–Ω–∞–π–¥–µ—Ç–µ –ø–æ–Ω–∞–¥ 30 –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–∏—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–±–Ω–∏—Ö –≤–µ—Ä—Å—ñ–π —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å SAP –ø–æ —Ä—ñ–∑–Ω–∏–º –Ω–∞–ø—Ä—è–º–∫–∞–º: Artificial intelligence (AI), Data and analytics, Business technology platform, Cloud ERP applications, CRM and customer experience, Financial management, Human capital management, Spend management, Supply chain management, Sustainability management, Industries (SAP Cloud for Energy, SAP
E-Mobility, SAP Sports One, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, public sector).

Advanced Trials ‚Äî —Ä–æ–∑—à–∏—Ä–µ–Ω—ñ –ø—Ä–æ–±–Ω—ñ –≤–µ—Ä—Å—ñ—ó –∑ –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤—ñ—Å—Ç—é –µ–∫—Å–ø–µ—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω—Ç—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –∑ –≤–ª–∞—Å–Ω–∏–º–∏ –¥–∞–Ω–∏–º–∏. –ó–∞ –ø–æ—Å–∏–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–æ –±—ñ–ª—å—à–µ 10 –ø—Ä–æ–±–Ω–∏—Ö –≤–µ—Ä—Å—ñ–π –ø–æ —Ç–∞–∫–∏–º –Ω–∞–ø—Ä—è–º–∫–∞–º: Business process transformation, Business technology platform, Cloud ERP applications, Supply chain management and Industries (SAP S/4HANA Utilities).

–ù–∞ —Ü–∏—Ö —Å—Ç–æ—Ä—ñ–Ω–∫–∞—Ö —Ç–∞–∫–æ–∂ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω—ñ demo videos —Ç–∞ product tours, —â–æ–± —à–≤–∏–¥–∫–æ –æ–∑–Ω–∞–π–æ–º–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è –∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü—ñ–æ–Ω–∞–ª–æ–º —Ç–∞ –ø–æ—Ç–µ–Ω—Ü—ñ–∞–ª–æ–º —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å SAP.

–¢–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤—ñ –≤–µ—Ä—Å—ñ—ó SAP ‚Äî —Ü–µ –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤—ñ—Å—Ç—å:

  • –¥–æ—Å–ª—ñ–¥–∏—Ç–∏, —è–∫ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è SAP —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–≥—Ä—É—é—Ç—å—Å—è —É –≤–∞—à—É IT-–µ–∫–æ—Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—É;
  • –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤—ñ—Ä–∏—Ç–∏ —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ—ó –æ–ø—Ç–∏–º—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-–ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—ñ–≤;
  • –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–µ—Å—Ç—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –®I-–º–æ–¥–µ–ª—ñ –¥–ª—è –∞–Ω–∞–ª—ñ—Ç–∏–∫–∏, –ø—Ä–æ–≥–Ω–æ–∑—É–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—è —Ç–∞ –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó.

–Ü–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ –¥–µ–º–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ—ó ‚Äî Value Journeys

SAP —Ç–∞–∫–æ–∂ –ø—Ä–æ–ø–æ–Ω—É—î Interactive Value Journey (IVJ) ‚Äî —Ü–µ –±–µ–∑–∫–æ—à—Ç–æ–≤–Ω—ñ —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ –¥–µ–º–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ—ó SAP, —â–æ –¥–æ–∑–≤–æ–ª—è—é—Ç—å –ø–æ–±–∞—á–∏—Ç–∏ —Ä–æ–±–æ—Ç—É –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-–ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—ñ–≤ —É —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ñ –≤ —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–º—É —Ä–µ–∂–∏–º—ñ. –ö–æ–∂–Ω–∞ –ø–æ–¥–æ—Ä–æ–∂ –º—ñ—Å—Ç–∏—Ç—å –ø–æ–∫—Ä–æ–∫–æ–≤—É —ñ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ü—ñ—é, –∫–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ä—ñ —Ç–∞ –≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤—ñ –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∞–¥–∏ –¥–∞–Ω–∏—Ö, —â–æ–± –∫–æ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç—É–≤–∞—á –º—ñ–≥ —à–≤–∏–¥–∫–æ –∑—Ä–æ–∑—É–º—ñ—Ç–∏, —è–∫ –ø—Ä–∞—Ü—é—î –∫–æ–Ω–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–∏–π —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ–π. –î–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø –≤—ñ–¥–∫—Ä–∏—Ç–∏–π –¥–ª—è –≤—Å—ñ—Ö, —Ç–æ–º—É IVJ —î –∑—Ä—É—á–Ω–∏–º —Å–ø–æ—Å–æ–±–æ–º –æ–∑–Ω–∞–π–æ–º–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è –∑ –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤–æ—Å—Ç—è–º–∏ SAP –±–µ–∑ —Ç–µ—Ö–Ω—ñ—á–Ω–æ—ó –ø—ñ–¥–≥–æ—Ç–æ–≤–∫–∏ —Ç–∞ –¥–æ–¥–∞—Ç–∫–æ–≤–∏—Ö —ñ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–ª—è—Ü—ñ–π.

SAP Business Technology Platform (Build and develop) ‚Äî —Ü—è —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∞ –ø–æ–¥–æ—Ä–æ–∂ –ø–æ–∫–∞–∑—É—î —è–∫ —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤–µ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –¥–æ–ø–æ–º–∞–≥–∞—î –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—è–º –ø—ñ–¥–≤–∏—â—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –µ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—å —ñ –ø—Ä–∏—Å–∫–æ—Ä—é–≤–∞—Ç–∏ —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤—É —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü—ñ—é. –£ –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∞–¥—ñ CIO –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—ó S.MART –≤–∏–∫–æ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–æ–≤—É—î —ñ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∏ SAP Build –¥–ª—è –æ–ø—Ç–∏–º—ñ–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ–π, —à–≤–∏–¥–∫–æ—ó —Ä–æ–∑—Ä–æ–±–∫–∏ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω—å —ñ –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—ñ–≤. –£ —Ä–µ–∑—É–ª—å—Ç–∞—Ç—ñ –¥–æ—Å—è–≥–Ω–µ–Ω–æ: –∫—Ä–∞—â–∏–π –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª—å –∑–∞–ø–∞—Å—ñ–≤ —ñ —É–∑–≥–æ–¥–∂–µ–Ω–Ω—è –º—ñ–∂ —Å–∫–ª–∞–¥–∞–º–∏ —Ç–∞ –º–∞–≥–∞–∑–∏–Ω–∞–º–∏, –ø—Ä–æ–∑–æ—Ä—ñ—Å—Ç—å —Ç–∞ —É–∑–≥–æ–¥–∂–µ–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—å –¥–∞–Ω–∏—Ö —É –≤—Å—ñ–π –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—ó, –≥–Ω—É—á–∫—ñ —Ö–º–∞—Ä–Ω—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è, —â–æ —à–≤–∏–¥–∫–æ –∞–¥–∞–ø—Ç—É—é—Ç—å—Å—è –¥–æ –∑–º—ñ–Ω —É –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å—ñ, —à–≤–∏–¥–∫–µ –≤–∏—è–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—è —Ç–∞ —É—Å—É–Ω–µ–Ω–Ω—è –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å–Ω–∏—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º –∑–∞–≤–¥—è–∫–∏ –∞–Ω–∞–ª—ñ—Ç–∏—Ü—ñ –π AI-–ø—ñ–¥–∫–∞–∑–∫–∞–º. –ü–µ—Ä–µ–≥–ª—è–Ω—É—Ç–∏ –ø–æ–¥–æ—Ä–æ–∂ –º–æ–∂–Ω–∞ –∑–∞ –ø–æ—Å–∏–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º ‚Äì –≤–æ–Ω–∞ —Å—Ç–∞—î –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–æ—é –ø—ñ—Å–ª—è —Å—Ç–≤–æ—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω—è –±–µ–∑–∫–æ—à—Ç–æ–≤–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ–±–ª—ñ–∫–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ –∑–∞–ø–∏—Å—É –Ω–∞ —Å–∞–π—Ç—ñ SAP.

SAP Business Suite ‚Äî —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∞ –ø–æ–¥–æ—Ä–æ–∂ –¥–µ–º–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É—î, —è–∫ SAP Business Suite –æ–±‚Äô—î–¥–Ω—É—î –¥–æ–¥–∞—Ç–∫–∏, –¥–∞–Ω—ñ —Ç–∞ —à—Ç—É—á–Ω–∏–π —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–ª–µ–∫—Ç —É —î–¥–∏–Ω—É –ø–ª–∞—Ç—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É –¥–ª—è —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—ñ–Ω–Ω—è –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å–æ–º. –£ —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ—ó –ø–æ–∫–∞–∑–∞–Ω–æ, —è–∫ –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—ó –º–æ–∂—É—Ç—å –≤–ø—Ä–æ–≤–∞–¥–∂—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–≥—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è, —â–æ –æ—Ö–æ–ø–ª—é—é—Ç—å –≤—Å—ñ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü—ñ—ó: –≤—ñ–¥ —Ñ—ñ–Ω–∞–Ω—Å—ñ–≤ —ñ –ª–∞–Ω—Ü—é–≥–∞ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞—á–∞–Ω–Ω—è –¥–æ HR —Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–æ–¥–∞–∂—ñ–≤.

  • –ú–æ–¥—É–ª—å–Ω–∏–π –ø—ñ–¥—Ö—ñ–¥: –≤–∏–±—ñ—Ä —Å–ø–µ—Ü—ñ–∞–ª—ñ–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—Ö –ø–∞–∫–µ—Ç—ñ–≤ –¥–ª—è —Ä—ñ–∑–Ω–∏—Ö –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-–ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—ñ–≤.
  • –Ñ–¥–∏–Ω–∞ —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞ –¥–∞–Ω–∏—Ö –∑ —Ä—ñ–∑–Ω–∏—Ö –¥–∂–µ—Ä–µ–ª, —â–æ –∑–∞–±–µ–∑–ø–µ—á—É—î –ø—Ä–æ–∑–æ—Ä—ñ—Å—Ç—å —ñ —É–∑–≥–æ–¥–∂–µ–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—å.
  • –í–±—É–¥–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–π –®–Ü: –∞–Ω–∞–ª—ñ—Ç–∏–∫–∞, –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—è, –∞–≥–µ–Ω—Ç-—Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –¥–ª—è –∫–æ–º–ø–ª–µ–∫—Å–Ω–æ—ó –ø—ñ–¥—Ç—Ä–∏–º–∫–∏ –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å—É.
  • –û—Ä—ñ—î–Ω—Ç–∞—Ü—ñ—è –Ω–∞ —Ö–º–∞—Ä—É —Ç–∞ –º–∞—Å—à—Ç–∞–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—å –¥–ª—è —Ä–æ–∑–≤–∏—Ç–∫—É –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—ó.

–¶–µ–π —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ–π –¥–æ–ø–æ–º–∞–≥–∞—î –æ—Ü—ñ–Ω–∏—Ç–∏, —è–∫ SAP Business Suite —Å—Ç–≤–æ—Ä—é—î –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤—É –¥–ª—è –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-—ñ–Ω–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ü—ñ–π —ñ —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤–æ—ó —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü—ñ—ó. –°—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω–∏–π –∑–∞ –ø–æ—Å–∏–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º –ø—ñ—Å–ª—è —Å—Ç–≤–æ—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω—è –æ–±–ª—ñ–∫–æ–≤–æ–≥–æ –∑–∞–ø–∏—Å—É SAP.

SAP Business AI ‚Äì –ø–ª–µ–π–ª–∏—Å—Ç SAPPHIRE 2025. –¶–µ–π –ø–ª–µ–π–ª–∏—Å—Ç –ø—Ä–∏—Å–≤—è—á–µ–Ω–∏–π –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤–æ—Å—Ç—è–º —à—Ç—É—á–Ω–æ–≥–æ —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–ª–µ–∫—Ç—É –≤ –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å—ñ (Business AI) –≤—ñ–¥ SAP, —è–∫—ñ –±—É–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω—ñ –Ω–∞ SAPPHIRE 2025. –£ –¥–æ–±—ñ—Ä—Ü—ñ –∑—ñ–±—Ä–∞–Ω—ñ —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ—ó (IVJ), —â–æ –ø–æ–∫–∞–∑—É—é—Ç—å, —è–∫ –®–Ü –¥–æ–ø–æ–º–∞–≥–∞—î –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—è–º –æ–ø—Ç–∏–º—ñ–∑—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å–∏, –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑—É–≤–∞—Ç–∏ —Ä—É—Ç–∏–Ω–Ω—ñ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ—ó —Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–∏–π–º–∞—Ç–∏ –∫—Ä–∞—â—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è –Ω–∞ –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤—ñ –¥–∞–Ω–∏—Ö.

–î–æ –ø–ª–µ–π–ª–∏—Å—Ç–∞ –≤—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å:

  • –æ–≥–ª—è–¥ –∫–ª—é—á–æ–≤–∏—Ö –Ω–æ–≤–∏–Ω–æ–∫ Business AI –≤—ñ–¥ SAP;
  • –¥–µ–º–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ—ó —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–∏—Ö –±—ñ–∑–Ω–µ—Å-—Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä—ñ—ó–≤ –∑ –≤–∏–∫–æ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º –®–Ü;
  • –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∞–¥–∏ —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–≥—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –®I —É —Ñ—ñ–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∏, –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü—ñ–π–Ω—ñ –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å–∏, –∫–ª—ñ—î–Ω—Ç—Å—å–∫–∏–π —Å–µ—Ä–≤—ñ—Å —Ç–∞ –ª–∞–Ω—Ü—é–≥–∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–∞—á–∞–Ω–Ω—è;
  • –ø–æ–∫–∞–∑ —Ç–æ–≥–æ, —è–∫ –®–Ü –ø—ñ–¥—Å–∏–ª—é—î –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—å –∫–æ–º–∞–Ω–¥ —ñ –ø—Ä–∏—à–≤–∏–¥—à—É—î —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤—É —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü—ñ—é.

–û–∑–Ω–∞–π–æ–º—Ç–µ—Å—è –∑–∞ –ø–æ—Å–∏–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º. –î–ª—è –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≥–ª—è–¥—É –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–Ω—å–æ —Å—Ç–≤–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–∏ –±–µ–∑–∫–æ—à—Ç–æ–≤–Ω–∏–π SAP-–∞–∫–∫–∞—É–Ω—Ç.

–°–ø—Ä–æ–±—É–π—Ç–µ SAP –±–µ–∑–∫–æ—à—Ç–æ–≤–Ω–æ ‚Äî —ñ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–∫–æ–Ω–∞–π—Ç–µ—Å—è, —è–∫ —à—Ç—É—á–Ω–∏–π —ñ–Ω—Ç–µ–ª–µ–∫—Ç, –∞–Ω–∞–ª—ñ—Ç–∏–∫–∞ —Ç–∞ –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—è –¥–æ–ø–æ–º–∞–≥–∞—é—Ç—å –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ—è–º –ø—Ä–∞—Ü—é–≤–∞—Ç–∏ –µ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ñ—à–µ –≤–∂–µ —Å—å–æ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—ñ.

entry.title: Real-time steering with LIVE planning
entry.content:
LIVE (Seamless) planning as the backend enabler for simplifications and real-time steering 

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning (THIS BLOG POST)
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real-time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In my previous blog post of our BDC Business Steering series, I highlighted the key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), explaining how they help organizations streamline planning and analytics processes, enhance decision-making, boost efficiency and drive business value.

SAP BDC delivers Seamless Planning, a unified enterprise planning paradigm enabled by deep integration between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere (DSP). Through this integration, SAC planning model data is stored directly in SAP Datasphere, providing native connectivity to SAP and non-SAP data sources as well as to SAP BDC Data Products. This ensures organizations can operate on trusted, consistent data structures fully aligned with operational data. Seamless Planning unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. SAC remains the user-friendly planning experience and calculation engine, while Datasphere serves as the authoritative, governed persistence layer for plan and master data, integrated with other data sources. This architecture provides flexibility and multiple extensibility options by leveraging DSP‚Äôs ETL capabilities or applying advanced ML/AI through SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Databricks.

The latest evolution of Seamless Planning brings the integration of external data sources directly into SAC planning models as Live Versions, as detailed by @MaxGander in an excellent recent blog post. Introduced in Q4 2025, the External Live Version Data Sources innovation significantly reduces traditional data-import workflows in SAC planning models and eliminates data movement between planning domains, enabling a fully integrated, real-time planning experience.

In this blog post, I will illustrate a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions in SAC planning powered by SAP Datasphere. The result is a real-time, holistic view of business insights that enhances steering agility, streamlines data management, and supports automated decision-making across the entire planning and analytics workflows.

A FEW WORDS ABOUT THE USE CASE EXAMPLE

 The example use case is about Brand Profitability Planning strategic process of aligning a company's branding strategies with its financial goals. The focus is on creating and maintaining a strong brand identity that not only resonates with customers but also drives long-term profitability.

With SAC and DSP Seamless Planning in SAP BDC, a Commerce Manager can quickly identify when brand commercial margin forecasts fall below budget and take proactive action by running simulations and predictive analyses using live connected reference data. They can also incorporate multiple influencers, integrated as external live data versions, to further refine projections. The CFO can then immediately assess the impact on the P&L, supported by real-time planning and analytics capabilities.

 The architecture and data flow are as follows:

  1. Actual profitability data from the SAP ERP system is stored in SAP Datasphere (DSP).
  2. This actual data is exposed as an external Live Version within the SAC Planning Brand Profitability Model, which resides in SAP DSP.
  3. Reference data (e.g. prior forecasts) is also integrated as an external Live Version in the same planning model.
  4. Influencer data used for predictive scenarios is integrated as an external Live Version to enrich the planning model.
  5. The SAC Planning Brand Profitability experience (stories, business logic, predictions, simulations, etc.) operates directly on these live data versions, while plan data is persisted into the underlying SAP DSP exposed table of the SAC Planning Brand Profitability Model.
  6. Real-time reporting and variance analysis are performed in SAP Analytics Cloud using the DSP Analytic Model.

STEP-BY-STEP EXECUTION

1. Brand Profitability Analysis

The Commerce Manager conducts multiple profitability analyses to identify underperforming brands and simulates strategies to improve their profitability. Analyzing the commercial figures indicates that we are currently under budget according to the current forecast. After a detailed analysis, examining each brand individually, identifies the responsible brand that requires attention and corrective measures to ensure the accuracy of the forecast plan.   

Step 1: Brand Profitability Analysis

Technical setup: The above SAC visualization story is built on top of a DSP Analytic Model for real-time variance analysis, integrating actuals and plan data through a DSP view that combines ERP actuals with the plan fact data from the SAC planning model. After each new forecast update is published, the plan data becomes real-time available in the variance analysis report‚Äîwith no additional data movements, replications, or delays.

DSP: Brand Profitability Analytic ModelDSP: Brand Profitability View (Actual and Plan)

2. Driver-based Simulations / Scenario Planning

The Commerce Manager initiates a new forecast by creating multiple scenarios for the key profitability drivers. Scenarios 1 and 2 are driver-based, with scenario specific inputs applied accordingly (e.g., Scenario 01: pessimistic, Scenario 02: optimistic). These scenarios leverage the reference dataset, such as the previous forecast, made available as an external Live Version. For variance analysis during the simulation process, prior year actual is also integrated in real-time through a Live Version in SAC Planning, extended also with the planning business logic on-the-fly (e.g., Gross Margin (%) and Commercial Margin (%) calculations are executed for the actual and plan versions) to provide immediate, accurate comparisons.

Step 2: Driver-based Simulations / Scenario Planning

Technical setup: Actuals are integrated as a Live Version into the SAC Planning Brand Profitability model, enabling on-the-fly variance analysis against plan versions and supporting account and measure level calculations directly on live version data. The source for this actuals Live Version is a DSP view exposed for consumption.

Previous Forecast data is also integrated as a Live Version and serves as the baseline for driver-based scenario plan version calculations, allowing SAC data actions to perform business calculation calculations directly on top of live versions.

SAC: Brand Profitability Planning Model with External Live Versions

 

DSP: Exposed Views for Consumption as External Live Versions in Planning

 

SAC: Data Action - Scenario Creation leveraging Ref.Data External Live View

3. Predictive Scenario Planning

The third scenario is prediction-based, leveraging various KPI influencers alongside external data (e.g., the CPI index) sourced from the DSP Marketplace. The Commerce Manager updates the influencer values for the predictive model, and once configured, the predictive scenario can be executed. In this example, the predictive scenario for Gross Sales uses an external Live Version as the baseline, integrating actual data, CPI data, and the manager‚Äôs forecasted influencer values directly within SAP DSP.

Step 3: Predictive Scenario Planning

Technical setup: The baseline version for the predictive scenario is connected as an External Live Version in the SAC Planning Brand Profitability model, integrating actual data, CPI data, and the Commerce Manager‚Äôs forecasted influencer values directly from SAP DSP plan fact table. The source for this Predictive Live Version is a DSP view activated for consumption. A multi-action then executes the predictive scenario and triggers the additional data-action calculation steps required to produce the complete commercial margin for the predictive scenario. You can find more details about Time Series Forecasting and Predictive Planning in SAC in the blog post.

DSP: Predictive View used as External Live Version in Predictive Scenario

SAC: Multi-action with Predictive Scenario Calculation

 4. Simulating and creating the new Brand Forecast

After identifying optimization opportunities, the Commerce Manager can simulate proposed adjustments and assess their potential impact using SAP Analytics Cloud‚Äôs out-of-the-box Value Driver capabilities. Optionally, a stochastic risk simulation (Monte Carlo Simulation) for each scenario can be performed through the embedded SAC Compass functionality. Once satisfied with the simulation results and the projected figures of the preferred scenario, the Commerce Manager proceeds to publish this scenario to the brand forecast.

Step 4: Simulating and creating the new Brand Forecast

Technical setup: Standard out-of-the-box simulation capabilities are configured in SAC. In the value driver tree widget, the LY Actual calculation is enabled on top of the External Live Version containing the actual data.SAC: LY Actual Measure calculation using External Live Version

5. Brand Forecast Allocation

The commerce manager will execute the allocation of Brand Forecast to all product and customer combinations based on the on last year Gross Sales proportionate.

Step 5: Brand Forecast Allocation

 

 Technical setup: Standard out-of-the-box allocation and advanced formulas data action steps are configured in SAC.

SAC: Data Action Allocation Step

 

6. Updated Forecast and Financial view Evaluation

Once the updated forecast allocation is executed and all unassigned data is done, the commerce manager has to publish the results. Having that done, all results are available in the Brand Profitability Analysis and the P&L in real-time!

Step 6: Updated Forecast and Financial View Evaluation

 Technical setup: As outlined in Step 1, the SAC visualizations are built on DSP Analytic Models for real-time variance analysis, integrating actuals and plan data through DSP views. Once a new forecast update is published, the plan data becomes immediately available in the brand profitability analysis reports, such as the P&L, without any additional data movements, replications, or delays. See below the DSP view used for real-time P&L reporting, which leverages the Brand Profitability view along with views from other planning domains.

DSP: P&L view

SUMMARY

In this blog post, I demonstrated a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions within the SAP BDC Seamless Planning architecture. This capability is a game changer, enabling real-time business steering by unifying actuals and plan data across planning domains to deliver a holistic, trusted view of performance.

Key takeaways from the use case:

  1. External Live Versions can be applied throughout the planning workflow‚Äîstories, data actions, predictions, calculations, and more.
  2. They enable robust variance analysis by enriching actuals with planning-model logic and calculations.
  3. Seamless Planning reduces data redundancy and lowers total cost of ownership.
  4. It provides the flexibility to decouple planning and reporting using DSP Analytic Model capabilities.
  5. Planning logic can be enriched through DSP‚Äôs ETL capabilities and advanced ML/AI extensions via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Databricks within SAP Business Data Cloud.

Additionally, SAP BDC has the potential to further enhance Seamless Planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that blend analytics with actionable workflows.
  • Enabling the direct consumption of BDC governed data products within planning processes.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks and Snowflake.

This is just the beginning‚Äîmore innovations are on the way!
